title: Can we say that one's opinion about oneself is wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. The way you view yourself is wrong only if you believe it is. Let me explain. Let’s say you think of yourself as not a very confident person. It’s likely that you will lack confidence because you don’t believe you’re confident. Therefore, your view of yourself isn’t wrong. Likewise, if you think you think you’re better looking than everyone you meet, that is your opinion and you are not wrong. Someone else could come to a different conclusion, but it’s your opinion about yourself that matters. Now, we can say that if someone says they have the IQ of a genius but they cannot pass a test to prove it, then they are wrong about that. But, if they’re talking figuratively and believe in their own mind they are a genius and thinking it makes them feel highly intelligent then guess what, they are a genius. Human beings experience reality based on what they believe to be true about themselves, even if they’re facts. Whatever you believe, you will find confirmation for it. If you think your view about yourself is always wrong, then you have a belief your view is wrong, when the view itself may be right.

Wrong? Always? I would say that we have our own perception about ourselves. I will also say that other people’s perceptions about us should be considered. Maybe other people misunderstand you or maybe you are in denial about who you are. What is your truth? Are there lies you are believing about the world? Can you take criticism? And are you interested in raising your EQ about yourself in terms of enhancing your self-awareness? I also don’t believe anything is right or wrong. This is binary thinking that can get us in trouble.

The following quote would sum it up to best extent :  “Before you raise your finger to point at someone, Make sure your hand is clean!!"

Others' views of you, may originate from interpretations of what is observable to them. And this may be independent of your experience, desire, and knowledge of your own circumstances. For example, a transgender woman may be viewed as a “man" by those who are going by what they observe. They don't see a woman. And a subset of those may actually have an interest in deliberately NOT seeing a woman. Is the transgender woman's view of herself wrong?
